Convergence and Heterogeneity. 
We evaluate the convergence rate, training time, and accuracy of Upcycled-FL under different parameter settings. We take Î»m=Î»,âˆ€msubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğœ†for-allğ‘š\lambda_{m}=\lambda,\forall m in experiments, while we observe similar results for time-varying Î»msubscriptğœ†ğ‘š\lambda_{m}. Table 1 compares the training/testing accuracy of different algorithms when the device heterogeneity is high (90% stragglers). The results show that Upcycled-FL outperforms both FedProx and FedAvg on all datasets (with appropriate Î¼ğœ‡\mu). While FedAvg achieves good performance on Synthetic(iid), it is not robust to heterogeneous data. When data is i.i.d., adding the proximal term Î¼2â€‹â€–Ï‰âˆ’Ï‰Â¯tâ€–2ğœ‡2superscriptnormğœ”superscriptÂ¯ğœ”ğ‘¡2\frac{\mu}{2}||\omega-\overline{\omega}^{t}||^{2} may hurt the performance. However, the proximal term can help stabilize the algorithm and significantly improve the performance in practical settings when data is heterogeneous; these observations are consistent with [2]. Importantly, Upcycled-FL is more robust to the level of statistical heterogeneity than FedProx as it could attain consistent improvements for all settings. In practice, Î¼ğœ‡\mu needs to be carefully tuned; with a carefully selected Î¼ğœ‡\mu, Upcycled-FL could achieve 2%âˆ¼7%similar-topercent2percent72\%\sim 7\% improvement on accuracy compared to FedProx.

Convergence and Heterogeneity. 
We evaluate the convergence rate, training time, and accuracy of Upcycled-FL under different parameter settings. We take Î»m=Î»,âˆ€msubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğœ†for-allğ‘š\lambda_{m}=\lambda,\forall m in experiments, while we observe similar results for time-varying Î»msubscriptğœ†ğ‘š\lambda_{m}. Table 1 compares the training/testing accuracy of different algorithms when the device heterogeneity is high (90% stragglers). The results show that Upcycled-FL outperforms both FedProx and FedAvg on all datasets (with appropriate Î¼ğœ‡\mu). While FedAvg achieves good performance on Synthetic(iid), it is not robust to heterogeneous data. When data is i.i.d., adding the proximal term Î¼2â€‹â€–Ï‰âˆ’Ï‰Â¯tâ€–2ğœ‡2superscriptnormğœ”superscriptÂ¯ğœ”ğ‘¡2\frac{\mu}{2}||\omega-\overline{\omega}^{t}||^{2} may hurt the performance. However, the proximal term can help stabilize the algorithm and significantly improve the performance in practical settings when data is heterogeneous; these observations are consistent with [2]. Importantly, Upcycled-FL is more robust to the level of statistical heterogeneity than FedProx as it could attain consistent improvements for all settings. In practice, Î¼ğœ‡\mu needs to be carefully tuned; with a carefully selected Î¼ğœ‡\mu, Upcycled-FL could achieve 2%âˆ¼7%similar-topercent2percent72\%\sim 7\% improvement on accuracy compared to FedProx.

Figure 3(a) and 3(b) demonstrate the performance (averaged loss and the respective privacy loss Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon) of (non-)private Upcylced-FL and private FedProx on synthetic data using objective perturbation.
As expected, private Upcycled-FL is much more stable and significantly improves both privacy and accuracy over private FedProx. This is because the private Upcycled-FL with less information leakage requires much less perturbation to attain the same privacy guarantee as private FedProx. In general, we observe that private Upcycled-FL can experience 9.5% less privacy loss than private FedProx, and meanwhile having 11.0% (or 11.5%) higher training (or testing) accuracy on average and reducing 48% of training time. We also conduct similar experiments using output perturbation (Figure 3(c) and 3(d)). Results show that on average, private
Upcycled-FL can experience 12.0% less privacy loss than private FedProx while having 6.1% (or 6.2%) higher training (or testing) accuracy; the training time is still reduced by 48% under Upcycled-FL.
